Expectation1: Ensuring financial stability for the family
Situation1: The family requires money for daily living expenses, and the parent needs to provide it
Situation2: They guide a patient on proper usage and potential side effects of a new prescription medication.
Story: I glanced at the clock on the pharmacy wall, my mind racing with numbers—rent, groceries, the kids’ school fees. My shift was almost over, but I needed the overtime pay to keep us afloat this month. Just as I was about to clock out, a patient approached the counter, clutching a new prescription. Her anxious eyes met mine, and I knew she needed more than a quick transaction. As a pharmacist, I was expected to provide thorough counseling, to ensure she understood every detail about her medication and its side effects. But as a parent, I felt the weight of my family’s needs pressing down on me, the urgency to get home and maybe pick up a second shift somewhere else. My heart pounded as I wrestled with the expectations—do I stay and give the patient the time she deserves, or do I rush home to my family, hoping the extra hours will be enough to keep us going?
